Question: I am building an application where I need to make some layout. Normally I use Relative Layout and custom views which makes my work however this time, I think of using Liner Layout so I made this below XML. My aim was to make a child linear layout inside a parent and make than child's gravity to "bottom" which will hold my two bottom, one should be right aligned and one should be left aligned.

```
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
android:layout_width="fill_parent"
android:layout_height="fill_parent"
android:paddingLeft="5dp"
android:paddingRight="5dp"
android:orientation="vertical" >

<LinearLayout
    android:layout_width="fill_parent"
    android:layout_height="fill_parent"
    android:orientation="horizontal"
    android:gravity="bottom"       
    >       
   <Button            
        android:gravity="left"
        android:id="@+id/button2"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:text="Previous" />
   <Button            
        android:id="@+id/button3"
        android:layout_gravity="right"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:text="Next"/>
</LinearLayout>

```

The child is sitting in the bottom however two views that is buttons are not aligned properly. Am I doing anything wrong, or can these things not be achieved through this Layout?

Answer:

1. I am building an application where I need to make some layout. Normally I use Relative Layout and custom views which make my work however, this time I think of using Linear Layout. My aim was to make a child linear layout inside a parent and make the child's gravity to "bottom" which will hold my two bottom, one to the left and one to the right.

```xml
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/xmlstar">
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
android:layout_width="match_parent"
android:layout_height="match_parent
android:orientation="horizontal" >
<Button 
android:layout_width="wrap_content"
android:layout_height="wrap_content"
android:gravity="bottom"       
>       
   <Button            
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:gravity="left"        
        android:layout_margin="5dp"       
   </Button>
   <Button            
        android:gravity="right"
        android:id="@+id/button2
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:layout_margin="5dp"       
   </Button>
</LinearLayout>

```

My goal was to make a child `LinearLayout` inside a parent and make the child's gravity to "bottom" which will hold my two bottom, one to the left and one to the right.

Question: I wish to create an online system to track some things (e.g., a database with children, where each child has 1 or more visits from doctors). I want the users to be able to enter data as well as search for it, especially from mobile devices. So, this is a custom mobile online DB app of modest but non-zero size.

I've looked into DabbleDB and Zoho Creator, looking for an easy solution that will have low-cost maintenance.

Although I feel my app is not too complicated, I find that if I want to do something slightly out of their mainstream, I hit walls. For example, dealing with many-to-many relationships, or with 100K records, or doing an involved mathematical calculation for a field.

What are people's experiences with these online DB apps? Should I keep pushing ahead, or just write a custom app myself?

Answer:

11111111

Your answer suggests that you should either continue pushing ahead or just write a custom app yourself based on your needs. Your options seem balanced. Here are a few suggestions to help you decide:

1. If You Decide:

     - **Balance Your Needs**: 
   - **Consider Community Feedback**:

Question: We have a SharePoint WSS site and some of our users on on the Mac OSX platform. Are there any tips or tricks to get a similar experience to Windows with document shares and calendars on the Mac?

Edit: Browsing a SharePoint WSS site on a Mac, whether using Firefox or Safari, has a very similar look and feel as it does on Windows IE. The similar experience I am looking for has to do with integrating the calendars, document shares, etc. into the desktop.

For example, with IE you can go to a calendar and select "Actions -> Connect to Outlook" and it will make the calendar visible and manageable from within Outlook.

Is there any way to get the Mac to work similarly?

Answer:

1: There are several ways to get the Mac to work similarly to the experience of Windows. Some of these include integrating calendars, shares shares, etc. into the desktop.

Are there any ways to get the Mac to work similarly?

Question: If I have calculated the sample mean, variance, skew and kurtosis of a set of data, how would I go about fitting a probability distribution to match these moments (i.e. choosing a probability distribution and optimizing its parameters to fit the sample moments). Are there any packages in R/MATLAB/etc. that are capable of this?

For context, I believe I can calculate these moments for a portfolio's return distribution, but I actually need a whole probability density function for the portfolio's returns in order to perform additional analysis.

Answer:

1. I would use a package such as `MATLAB` or `R` which provides functions for fitting a probability distribution to match these moments. i.e., I would choose a distribution function and optimize its parameters to fit the sample moments. The process involves selecting an appropriate distribution function, like a normal distribution, and using optimization techniques to optimize its parameters to match the sample moments accurately. 

This approach requires selecting an appropriate distribution function, like a normal distribution, and utilizing optimization techniques to optimize its parameters to match the sample moments. 

Therefore, packages like MATLAB or R, which provide functions for fitting a distribution to match these moments are indeed capable of this task.

For example, in MATLAB, you can use the `fitdist` function to fit a distribution to match these moments. 

In R, you can use the `fitdistr` function from the `MASS` package to fit a distribution to match these moments. 

The process involves selecting an appropriate distribution function, like a normal distribution, and using optimization techniques to optimize its parameters to match the sample moments.

The choice of an appropriate distribution function and optimization of its parameters to match the sample moments is indeed capable with the use of packages like MATLAB or R, which provide functions for fitting a distribution to match these moments. 

Therefore, packages like MATLAB or R, which provide functions for fitting a distribution to match these moments are indeed capable of this task.

Question: I will be explaining Bitcoin to a non-technical group and I am hoping somebody can provide me with a very basic visual analogy of the crypto-currency mining process.

My half-baked idea, was to somehow describe the mining process as partaking in a complex word search. Hopefully getting my group to visualize a large pool table sized word search (block) and have them imagining searching for a 30 alphanumeric character identifier (wallet). Describing the blockchain as a city sized word-search on top of 21 million pool tables?

* Is this a good analogy to use, or is there a better/more applicable one?
* Using (and adding to) the best analogy, how can I explain the difference in mining with CPU/GPU/ASIC and why the ASIC hardware is the quickest?

1
/2
